abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Gazelle
            Restoration Project for Papua New Guinea (PNG) were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: involvement by several donors with
            different financing and disbursement procedures and
            information requirements imposed a considerable
            administrative burden on Gazelle Restoration Authority (GRA)
            administrative and engineering staff, in particular. In
            addition, reserving Bank-financing for critical components
            for improving the quality of life for displaced communities
            will have lessened the adverse impact of problems
            experienced with the European Union (EU) financing mechanism
            by accelerating provision of basic services in relocation
            sites as well as intensifying the dialogue on social and
            livelihood aspects. The assessment at appraisal indicated
            that operations and maintenance (O&M) on project assets
            will be administratively and financially manageable by all
            responsible agencies. The adverse impact on provincial
            revenues replacement of the provincial sales tax by the
            national value-added tax apparently undercut the
            province's longstanding tradition of adequate O&M,
            something which could not have been anticipated. The
            province's present limited revenue authority and
            dependence on government transfers highlights the need for a
            thorough review of the current arrangements. The use by GRA
            of a contract administration manual and enhanced risk
            management measures project restructuring in 2005 was
            effective in minimizing further cost escalation and
            implementation delays. While, implementation delays in the
            early years were largely out of the GRA's control,
            these tools and techniques are transferable and could
            generate major efficiency gains on development projects
            generally in PNG.
